verses.text: When Jabin king of Hazor heard of this, he sent word to Jobab king of Madon, to the king of Shimron, to the king of Achshaph,
verses.comment: Names preserved as in the original; 'heard of this' refers to Joshua's previous victories.

verses.text: and to the kings who were in the north hill country, the Arabah south of Kinnereth, in the lowland, and in Naphoth-dor on the west,
verses.comment: Geographical terms clarified for modern readers; original places maintained.

verses.text: to the Canaanites in the east and the west, the Amorites, Hittites, Perizzites, and Jebusites in the hill country, and the Hivites under Hermon in the land of Mizpah.
verses.comment: Lists all the groups involved as in the Hebrew; tribal names unchanged.

verses.text: They came out with all their armies, a multitude as numerous as the sand on the seashore, with many horses and chariots.
verses.comment: 'Numerous as the sand on the seashore' is a literal rendering of the Hebrew idiom.

verses.text: All these kings joined their forces and came and camped together at the waters of Merom to fight against Israel.
verses.comment: Merom kept as in original; simple verb tenses used for clarity.

verses.text: And the LORD said to Joshua, 'Do not be afraid of them, for tomorrow at this time I will give them all over slain before Israel. You shall hamstring their horses and burn their chariots with fire.'
verses.comment: 'Hamstring' is a close literal of Hebrew; direct speech preserved.

verses.text: So Joshua and all his army came suddenly against them by the waters of Merom and fell upon them.
verses.comment: Simple narrative maintained.

verses.text: And the LORD gave them into the hand of Israel, and they struck them and chased them as far as Great Sidon and Misrephoth-maim, and eastward to the valley of Mizpeh. They struck them until none were left.
verses.comment: Geographic names retained; idiomatic phrases rendered simply.

verses.text: And Joshua did to them just as the LORD had told him: he hamstrung their horses and burned their chariots with fire.
verses.comment: Literal rendering of actions as commanded.

verses.text: And Joshua turned back at that time and captured Hazor and struck its king with the sword, for Hazor before had been the head of all these kingdoms.
verses.comment: Sequence and reason for Hazor's destruction stated clearly.

verses.text: And they struck every person in it with the edge of the sword, devoting them to destruction. There was no one left who breathed. He burned Hazor with fire.
verses.comment: 'Devoting them to destruction' is a translation of Hebrew 'herem.'

verses.text: And Joshua captured all the cities of those kings and struck them with the edge of the sword, devoting them to destruction, just as Moses the servant of the LORD had commanded.
verses.comment: Consistent terminology used for Moses' command and Joshua's obedience.

verses.text: But none of the cities that stood on mounds did Israel burn, except Hazor alone; Joshua burned it.
verses.comment: A 'mound' translates Hebrew 'tel,' meaning a fortified city.

verses.text: And all the spoil of these cities and the livestock, the people of Israel took for themselves. But every person they struck with the edge of the sword until they had destroyed them, not leaving anyone who breathed.
verses.comment: Spoil and livestock differentiated from people; faithful to Hebrew structure.

verses.text: Just as the LORD had commanded Moses his servant, so Moses commanded Joshua, and so Joshua did; he left nothing undone of all that the LORD had commanded Moses.
verses.comment: Chain of command and obedience clearly outlined.

verses.text: So Joshua took all that land, the hill country and all the Negev, all the land of Goshen, the lowland, the Arabah, the hill country of Israel and its lowlands,
verses.comment: Land names kept as in the original for accuracy.

verses.text: from Mount Halak, which rises towards Seir, as far as Baal-gad in the valley of Lebanon below Mount Hermon. And he captured all their kings and struck them down and killed them.
verses.comment: Geographic boundaries made explicit for clarity.

verses.text: Joshua made war a long time with all those kings.
verses.comment: Duration stated directly as in the source text.

verses.text: There was not a city that made peace with the people of Israel, except the Hivites, the inhabitants of Gibeon. They took them all in battle.
verses.comment: Clarifies exception of Gibeon; exact parallel to text.

verses.text: For it was the LORD who hardened their hearts to fight against Israel, so that they might be devoted to destruction, having no mercy, but be destroyed, just as the LORD had commanded Moses.
verses.comment: Theological statement about God's sovereignty preserved; 'devoted to destruction' as herem.

verses.text: And Joshua came at that time and cut off the Anakim from the hill country: from Hebron, from Debir, from Anab, and from all the hill country of Judah, and from all the hill country of Israel. Joshua devoted them to destruction with their cities.
verses.comment: 'Cut off' translates a Hebrew idiom for eradication.

verses.text: None of the Anakim were left in the land of Israel; only in Gaza, in Gath, and in Ashdod did some remain.
verses.comment: Notes the survival of some Anakim away from the main area.

verses.text: So Joshua took control of the whole land, just as the LORD had spoken to Moses. And Joshua gave it as an inheritance to Israel, according to their divisions by tribes. Then the land rested from war.
verses.comment: Inheritance and division by tribe emphasized as in the Hebrew; 'rested from war' captures the significance of peace.
